conversation.text: Hi, I am a cooking chatbot. Would you like to learn how to baste a chicken today?
Sure! Do we cook with an oven?
We will be using a grill.
evidence: You can use either a charcoal or gas grill

conversation.text: You are going to start by heating your grill. Feel free to use a charcoal or a gas grill. You will be brushing on a marinade.

Great! It is best to use chicken pieces such as thighs breasts, drumsticks or wings. They will cook much faster than a whole bird. You may marinate your chicken first or brush the marinade on as you grill.
evidence: Choose chicken thighs, breasts, wings, or drumsticks, which cook more quickly than a whole bird.

conversation.text: What can I do to let the chicken fully absorb the sauce?
I like to cut a few slits in the chicken so the marinade really gets in there. If you plan in advance you can also marinade overnight.

Using tongs, place the chicken on the grill with the skin side down. Put the lid on and cook for 3 minutes. After 3 minutes turn your chicken over and brush the chicken with marinade. Replace lid and continue cooking.
evidence: Place your chicken on the grill skin-side down with tongs

conversation.text: I have finished that. What's next please?
You will want to continue basting the chicken every 5 minutes until it is cooked. Make sure to check the temperature as different sizes take different amounts of time to cook.
evidence: Baste the chicken every 5 minutes until it is cooked.

conversation.text: Thanks! I just checked the chicken, and it looks like the inner part near bones is still raw with blood, but the outside is crispy.
You will want to use a thermometer and make sure the internal temperature reaches at least 165 F/ 74 C. That is when you will know the chicken if cooked.
evidence: The chicken is ready when the internal temperature reaches at least 165° F (74° C).

conversation.text: I see. Hmmm I think it's cooked now.

Awesome! It is going to be so good. Remove you chicken to a clean plate. Tent the pieces in foil for 5 minutes to rest and then dinner is ready to be served! I like to serve this with a salad or vegetables and a baked potato. Enjoy!!
evidence: Use tongs to move your cooked chicken onto a clean plate.

procedure.description: Use a clean grill and bring it to the desired heat for your recipe. You can use either a charcoal or gas grill to baste your chicken. Basting on the grill is about adding flavor thorough periodic brushing with a marinade rather than a fat. Brushing your chicken with a fat, such as butter, over an open flame is not advised and may be a fire hazard.

procedure.summary: Use chicken parts instead of a whole chicken.
procedure.description: Choose chicken thighs, breasts, wings, or drumsticks, which cook more quickly than a whole bird. You can marinate your chicken pieces for additional flavor before grilling.

procedure.summary: Place your chicken on the grill skin-side down with tongs.
procedure.description: If your marinade is high in sugar,  place the chicken towards the outer rim of the grill to start. This will keep the sugar from burning during cooking. Replace the lid of the grill, and let the chicken cook for 3 minutes.

Remove the lid of the grill, and use tongs to turn the pieces of chicken, so that they are now grill-side up. Use a silicone brush to coat the chicken pieces with a light coat of marinade. Replace the lid and cook for 5 more minutes. Only use marinade that has not been in contact with raw poultry to baste the meat. You can reserve some marinade to baste before marinating the chicken.

procedure.summary: Baste the chicken every 5 minutes until it is cooked.
procedure.description: Use a meat thermometer to check the internal temperature of the chicken. The chicken is ready when the internal temperature reaches at least 165° F (74° C).. If you’re grilling chicken pieces of varying sizes, take the temperature in a chicken thigh, which will often take the longest to cook.

procedure.summary: Remove the chicken from the grill.
procedure.description: Use tongs to move your cooked chicken onto a clean plate. Tent the pieces in foil, and let them rest for 5 minutes. Dinner is served.
